questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used to prevent delayed ischemia in the acute phase of subarachnoid hemorrhage?
questions.explanation:
Nimodipine
  • 30–60 mg IV for 5–14 days, followed by 360 mg orally for 7 days.
  • Prevents delayed ischemia in the acute phase of SAH.

Aneurysm Management
  • Endovascular coiling
  • Surgical clipping

Arteriovenous malformation Management
  • Surgical removal.
  • Ligation of feeding or draining blood vessels.
  • Injection of material to occlude fistula or draining veins.

Complications Treatment
  • Obstructive hydrocephalus: May need shunt drainage.
  • Delayed cerebral ischaemia (vasospasm): Treated with vasodilators.
  • Hyponatraemia: Managed by fluid restriction.
  • Systemic complications (immobility): Manage chest infections and venous thrombosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with progressive weakness in his arms and legs over the past three months. On examination, he has hyperreflexia in the upper and lower extremities and bilateral weakness is noted with poorly localized, burning pain and spared sensation in the perineal and sacral areas. Based on the presentation, which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Causes

Intramedullary Tumors:

  • Ependymomas
  • Astrocytomas
  • Hemangioblastomas
  • Abscesses (pyogenic or tuberculous abscesses) can create masses within the spinal cord.
  • Multiple sclerosis: Inflammatory demyelinating lesions may cause intramedullary effects.
  • Trauma
  • Cystic lesions: Such as syringomyelia, where a cyst forms within the spinal cord.

Clinical features
  • Motor Symptoms: Weakness or paralysis in the limbs, typically presenting as bilateral weakness.
  • Reflex Changes: Hyperreflexia and spasticity below the level of the lesion.
  • Pain: Poorly localized, burning pain and spared sensation in the perineal and sacral areas(sacral sparing).

Diagnosis
  • MRI of the Spine: The gold standard for identifying intramedullary lesions.
  • CT Scan
  • Neurological Examination: Detailed assessment to identify the level and extent of dysfunction.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of radicular pain on the lower back associated with loss of sensations over sacrum and urinary incontinence. There was weakness, started over lower limbs one month back and now weakness is present over upper limbs. What is the ideal imaging of choice to diagnose this condition?
questions.explanation:
Causes
  • Intradural: Benign Neurofibroma; Slow onset of symptoms seen
  • Extradural: Spinal metastases from Breast/lung/Prostate cancer; Relatively rapid onset of manifestations seen

Clinical features
  • Radicular (root) pain along the nerve root involved
  • Early sacral sensory loss
  • Ascending spastic paralysis starting from lower limbs
  • Bladder involvement - early

questions.text: Which among the following is the least likely manifestation in this spinal cord lesion (as shown below)?

options.label: A
options.text: I/L loss of vibration sense at the same level

options.label: B
options.text: C/L loss of pain at the same level

options.label: C
options.text: I/L loss of vibration sense 2 segments below the level of lesion

options.label: D
options.text: C/L loss of pain 2 segments below the level of lesion

questions.correct_answer: B. C/L loss of pain at the same level
questions.explanation:
Ipsilateral (I/L)

Contralateral (C/L)

At the level of lesion
  • CST: LMN paralysis
  • Dorsal column: Loss of vibration and proprioception
  • Radicular pain +

-

Below the level of lesion
  • CST: UMN paralysis
  • Dorsal column: Loss of vibration and proprioception
  • Spinothalamic tract: Loss of Pain and Temperature

questions.text: A 30 year old vegetarian female was referred to Neurology OPD with complaints of progressive weakness of lower limbs, numbness, difficulty walking and recent onset forgetfulness. On examination, there was B/L loss of vibration sense, Deep tendon reflexes - absent, Babinski-positive and Positive Romberg sign was noted. Peripheral blood smear done was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Subacute combined degeneration of Spinal cord

questions.correct_answer: A. Subacute combined degeneration of Spinal cord
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Reference:

Description
  • Reversible myelopathy mainly involving Dorsal column and Pyramidal column tracts

Etiology
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency: Nutritional (vegetarians), Pernicious anemia, post-gastrectomy, Diphyllobothrium infection

Clinical features
  • Weakness: Corticospinal tract (CST)/Pyramidal tract involvement
  • Loss of vibration and proprioception: Dorsal column tract involvement
  • Ataxia: Romberg sign positive
  • DTR: Absent (Peripheral neuropathy), Babinski sign: Positive (CST involvement)
  • Dementia: Reversible with therapy
  • Hyperpigmentation of interphalangeal joints

Investigations
  • Vitamin B12 assay: Methyl malonate/Homocysteine levels estimation
  • Peripheral blood smear: May reveal macrocytosis with hypersegmented neutrophils
 
  • NOTE: SACD can occur without macrocytosis as well

Management
  • Vitamin B12 supplementation

Differential diagnosis
  • Hypocupric myelopathy: Serum Cu2+ levels should be checked

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with sudden symmetrical onset of both lower extremity weakness, numbness, and urinary retention. She reports a history of a respiratory tract infection two weeks ago. Neurological examination reveals reduced muscle strength and sensory loss below the mid-thoracic region, along with hyperreflexia. MRI of the spine shows a focal area of increased T2 signal in the thoracic spinal cord without evidence of compression. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Introduction
  • Acquired focal inflammatory disorder of spinal cord

Etio- pathogenesis
  • Idiopathic: Most common
  • Post-infectious: Usually Enterovirus, Herpes, HIV
  • Inflammatory/Autoimmune: Ankylosing spondylitis, APLA syndrome, Behcet disease, RA, Scleroderma
  • Multifocal CNS disorders: Multiple sclerosis, Neurosarcoidosis

Clinical features
  • Motor: Sudden onset B/L usually symmetric rapid paralysis initially flaccidity, and later spasticity sets in.
  • Sensory: Pain, Dysaesthesia, Paraesthesia
  • Autonomic: Bowel/bladder disturbances +, impotence +
  • Backache: Corresponding to the level of lesion

Diagnosis
  • T2-MRI: Focal Hyperintense signals within the spinal cord
  • CSF Analysis: To rule out other infectious/inflammatory etiology, elevated IgG index may be present
  • Histopathology: Perivascular infiltration of monocytes/lymphocytes + demyelination +/- axonal injury

Management
  • First line: High dose IV Glucocorticoids
  • Plasmapheresis
  • Other immunomodulators: Cyclophosphamide, Mycophenolate, Rituximab

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with sudden onset lower back pain and bilateral lower limb weakness. On examination, there is saddle anesthesia, knee jerk-intact and ankle jerk-absent. What is the most likely diagnosis and its corresponding onset of bladder involvement?

options.label: A
options.text: Conus medullaris syndrome, Early bladder involvement

options.label: B
options.text: Cauda Equina Syndrome, Early bladder involvement

options.label: C
options.text: Conus medullaris syndrome, Late bladder involvement

options.label: D
options.text: Cauda Equina Syndrome, Late bladder involvement

questions.correct_answer: A. Conus medullaris syndrome, Early bladder involvement
questions.explanation:
Conus Medullaris syndrome

Cauda Equina syndrome

Nerve roots
  • S1-S5 (Purely sacral)
  • Lumbar + Sacral

Presentation
  • Sudden and bilateral symmetric
  • Back Pain- more severe
  • Gradual and unilateral asymmetric
  • Pain- less severe

Radicular pain
  • Severe
  • Mild-moderate

Knee jerk
  • Preserved
  • Absent

Ankle jerk
  • Absent
  • Absent

Sensory loss
  • More localized to perianal area: Saddle anesthesia +
  • Patchy loss along the lower limb: Radicular pattern distribution

Motor loss
  • Less marked, symmetric
  • More marked, asymmetric

Bowel/bladder involvement
  • Frequent and early onset
  • Late onset

Impotence
  • Present
  • Less frequent

questions.text: A 54-year-old male has a herniated disk that has damaged his L3-L5 nerve roots. Which of the following is least likely to be his clinical feature?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Compression and disruption of the nerve roots from the distal spinal cord (typically L1-L5), often resulting from damage (secondary to trauma, tumors, herniated discs, or spinal stenosis ) to L3-L5 nerve roots

Clinical features

 

- Back pain and sciatica (Option A ruled out)

- Bladder dysfunction (retention or incontinence)

- Bowel dysfunction (retention or incontinence)

- Saddle anesthesia (Option B ruled out)

- Sexual dysfunction (impotence in men). (Option D ruled out)

- Motor or sensory deficits in the legs, often asymmetric.

- Lower motor neuron signs: areflexia, hypotonia, atrophy.

- Decreased rectal tone.

- Absent bulbocavernosus reflex (Option C)

Diagnosis

- Urgent MRI with sagittal and axial T1 and T2 sequences is the gold standard.

- CT myelogram for patients contraindicated for MRI.

- Bladder scan to check post-void residual volume for urinary retention.

Management

Surgical decompression (laminectomy, discectomy, or sequestrectomy) with early neurosurgical or orthopedic consultation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is wrong on conus medullaris?

options.label: B
options.text: Affects the sacral and single coccygeal segments

options.label: D
options.text: Loss of muscle strength on inner thighs

questions.correct_answer: D. Loss of muscle strength on inner thighs
questions.explanation:
Definition

Tapered caudal termination of the spinal cord (Option A ruled out), comprising the sacral and single coccygeal segments (Option B ruled out)

Symptoms
  • Bilateral saddle anesthesia (S3–S5) (Option C ruled out) involving the perineum, inner thighs, and buttocks.
  • Prominent urinary retention, incontinence, and lax anal tone.
  • Impotence is common due to the involvement of sacral segments.
  • Largely preserved muscle strength.(Option D)
  • Absent bulbocavernosus reflex (S2–S4) and anal reflex (S4–S5).
  • Typically minimal or absent pain.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive weakness and sensory loss in her arms, along with muscle wasting in her hands. MRI reveals a large intramedullary spinal cord tumor, with an associated syrinx. What is the management?
questions.explanation:
Diagnosis

MRI to detect syrinx cavities, spinal cord enlargement, assess Chiari malformation, and determine hydrocephalus.


 

Treatment
  • Chiari malformation treatment: Suboccipital craniectomy, cervical laminectomy, dural graft placement.
  • Hydrocephalus with Chiari: Shunting precedes syrinx correction.
  • Syrinx secondary to trauma/infection: Decompression and drainage (shunt or fenestration).
  • Syrinx due to intramedullary spinal cord tumors: Tumor resection is preferred.
 

Note: Patients with minimal symptoms do not require surgery and are monitored with clinical and imaging follow-up.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about syringomyelia is wrong?

options.label: A
options.text: A developmental cavity in the cervical cord

options.label: B
options.text: Symptoms begin in adolescence or early adulthood

options.label: C
options.text: The majority linked with Chiari type 2 malformation

options.label: D
options.text: Sensory loss in a cape distribution

questions.correct_answer: C. The majority linked with Chiari type 2 malformation
questions.explanation:
Definition

A developmental cavity in the cervical cord (Option A ruled out) that can enlarge or remain asymptomatic.

Onset & Progression

Symptoms begin in adolescence or early adulthood (Option B ruled out), progress irregularly, and may undergo spontaneous arrest.

Common Association

More than half of cases are linked with Chiari type 1 malformations (cerebellar tonsils protrude through the foramen magnum and cervical spinal canal). (Option C)

Pathophysiology

Possibly related to interference with CSF flow, particularly due to Chiari malformations.

Presentation

Dissociated sensory loss (pain and temperature loss, touch and vibration spared).

Areflexic weakness in upper limbs.

Suspended sensory loss in a cape distribution (nape, shoulders, upper arms, hands). (Option D ruled out)

Muscle wasting in neck, shoulders, arms, hands; absent/asymmetric reflexes in arms.

As syrinx expands: Spasticity, leg weakness, bladder/bowel dysfunction, Horner's syndrome.

Facial numbness from trigeminal damage (C2 level or above).

Additional Symptoms

Chiari-associated symptoms: Cough-induced headache, neck, arm, or facial pain.

Syringobulbia: Palatal/vocal cord paralysis, dysarthria, nystagmus, vertigo, tongue weakness.

questions.text: Which gene mutation is primarily associated with hyperkalemic periodic paralysis?

A 60-year-old female is admitted to the ICU following a subarachnoid hemorrhage. On examination, she is stuporous, exhibits intermittent reflex posturing and has severe motor deficits. Her Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is 8. What is her grade of subarachnoid hemorrhage according to both the Hunt-Hess scale and the World Federation of Neurosurgical Societies (WFNS) scale?
questions.explanation:
Grading Scales for Subarachnoid Hemorrhage

GRADE

HUNT-HESS SCALE

WORLD FEDERATION OF NEUROSURGICAL SOCIETIES (WFNS) SCALE

1

Mild headache, normal mental status, no cranial nerve or motor findings

GCS score 15, no motor deficits

2

Severe headache, normal mental status, may have cranial nerve deficit

GCS score 13–14, no motor deficits

3

Somnolent, confused, may have cranial nerve or mild motor deficit

GCS score 13–14, with motor deficits

4

Stupor, moderate to severe motor deficit, may have intermittent posturing

GCS score 7–12, with or without motor deficits

5

Coma, reflex posturing or flaccid

GCS score 3–6, with or without motor deficits

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with a sudden, severe headache described as the "worst of their life." A non-contrast head CT scan is performed but returns negative. Despite this, the suspicion of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) remains high. What is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Repeat the head CT scan in 24 hours

options.label: B
options.text: Lumbar puncture (LP) to assess for xanthochromia

options.label: D
options.text: Perform a Time-of-Flight Magnetic Resonance Angiography (TOF-MRA)

questions.correct_answer: B. Lumbar puncture (LP) to assess for xanthochromia
questions.explanation:
Vasospasm Prediction
  • The extent and location of blood on the CT scan help locate the aneurysm, explain neurologic deficits, and predict vasospasm risk.
  • Large clots (>5 × 3 mm) in basal cisterns or blood layers >1 mm in cerebral fissures indicate higher vasospasm risk, particularly in MCA and ACA territories.
  • CT scans are less predictive of vasospasm in vertebral, basilar, or posterior cerebral arteries.

Monitoring and Cardiac Implications
  • Electrolytes: Close monitoring (daily or twice daily) of electrolytes, especially during the first 2 weeks due to the risk of hyponatremia.
  • ECG Changes: SAH can cause ST-segment and T-wave changes similar to cardiac ischemia, with prolonged QRS, increased QT interval, and T-wave abnormalities.
    • Catecholamine Surge: SAH can lead to myocardial injury due to excessive catecholamine release, causing reversible cardiomyopathy.
    • Echocardiography Findings: Shows regional wall motion abnormalities corresponding to sympathetic nerve distribution, sparing the ventricular apex.
    • Troponin Elevation: Common but typically asymptomatic.
    • Ventricular Dysrhythmias: Rare

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe headache, described as "the worst headache of her life." She was unresponsive at home, and, on arrival, was stuporous, with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 10. A CT scan confirms a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). On the fourth day of her hospitalisation, she becomes increasingly drowsy, and her speech slows down. A repeat CT scan reveals no new haemorrhage or infarct. Her serum sodium level is 125 mEq/L. What is the most likely cause of this patient's deterioration?

options.label: D
options.text: Hyponatremia due to cerebral salt-wasting syndrome

questions.correct_answer: D. Hyponatremia due to cerebral salt-wasting syndrome
questions.explanation:
Subarachnoid hemorrhage- Delayed neurological deficits

Rerupture
  • Incidence: ~30% in the first month, with peak in the first 7 days.
  • Mortality rate: 50%.
  • Prevention: Early treatment eliminates risk.

Hydrocephalus
  • Acute Hydrocephalus: Causes stupor/coma; managed by external ventricular drain.
  • Subacute Hydrocephalus: Develops over days/weeks; causes drowsiness, slowed thinking, and incontinence.
    • Diagnosed via CT, CTA, TCD ultrasound, or x-ray angiography. (Option B ruled out)
  • Chronic Hydrocephalus: Weeks/months after SAH, with symptoms like gait difficulty, incontinence, or cognitive impairment.

Delayed Cerebral Ischemia (DCI)

(Option C ruled out)
  • Cause: Vasospasm of arteries at the brain’s base, causing ischemia and infarction (~30% of patients).
  • Onset: 4–14 days after hemorrhage (peaks at 7 days).
  • Mechanism: Triggered by blood clots/ breakdown products. More surrounding blood increases vasospasm risk.
  • Symptoms: Sudden focal deficits, mental decline, fluctuating symptoms.
  • Detection: X-ray angiography, TCD ultrasound, or CTA.
  • Treatment: CSF drainage, mannitol/ hypertonic saline, hemicraniectomy, moderate hypothermia.

Hyponatremia
  • Onset: Occurs in the first 2 weeks post-SAH due to natriuresis and volume depletion (hyponatremia + hypovolemia).
  • Cause: Involves atrial and brain natriuretic peptides (cerebral salt-wasting syndrome).
  • Treatment: Resolves in 1–2 weeks. Free-water restriction is avoided to reduce stroke risk.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a sudden, severe headache described as "the worst headache of her life." She also reports vomiting. Imaging confirms a subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH) due to a rupture of aneurysm at the posterior communicating artery and internal carotid junction. Which of the following clinical features is most likely associated with this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Subarachnoid hemorrhage- Clinical features and features based on location of bleed

Unruptured Aneurysms
  • Typically asymptomatic but may cause cranial nerve or brain parenchyma compression (mass effect).
  • Prodromal Symptoms:
    • Third Cranial Nerve Palsy: Seen with an expanding aneurysm at the posterior communicating artery and internal carotid junction. Symptoms include pupillary dilation, ipsilateral light reflex loss, and eye pain.
 
  • Sixth Nerve Palsy: May suggest an aneurysm in the cavernous sinus. (Option A ruled out)
  • Visual Field Defects: May occur with an aneurysm in the supraclinoid carotid or anterior cerebral artery (ACA). (Option B ruled out)
  • Occipital/ Cervical Pain: Seen with posterior inferior or anterior inferior cerebellar artery aneurysms. (Option D ruled out)
  • Eye/Temple Pain: Expanding middle cerebral artery (MCA) aneurysms can cause pain in or behind the eye and temple.

Ruptured Aneurysms
  • Sudden ICP increase: Occurs at the moment of rupture, often causing transient loss of consciousness in nearly 50% of patients.
  • Headache:
    • Excruciating headaches may precede before the rupture, but most patients report severe headache after regaining consciousness.
    • The primary symptom is a sudden severe headache during exertion, often described as "the worst headache of my life".
    • Some cases may present with moderate headache or changes in usual headache patterns.
    • Additional Symptoms: Generalized headache with neck stiffness and vomiting is common.
  • Focal Neurologic Deficits:
    • May occur if the aneurysm bleeds into the brain or subdural space, causing a hematoma.
    • Deficits include: Hemiparesis, aphasia, mental slowness (abulia).
  • Severe Cases: 10% of patients may lose consciousness for several days due to significant bleeding.
  • Sentinel Bleeds: Small, earlier ruptures causing unexplained headache can precede major SAH, signaling imminent hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female presents to the ER with a sudden onset of the "worst headache of her life." A CT scan confirms a subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH). After stabilization, further imaging reveals an aneurysm in the posterior circulation. Her relatives informed her that she had a past history of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). Which of the following is most strongly associated with an increased risk of rupture of this aneurysm? A) Aneurysm size of 3 cm B) Location in the posterior circulation C) Hypertension D) Age over 60 years E) History of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD)
questions.explanation:
Subarachnoid hemorrhage
  • Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH): Blood accumulation in the subarachnoid space.
  • Causes: Often due to aneurysm rupture (~85%) or trauma.
  • Non-traumatic SAH is most commonly caused by the rupture of a saccular aneurysm.
  • Clinical Impact: High mortality and morbidity; often presents with a sudden, severe headache (worst headache of life).
  • Complications: Seizures, vasospasm, hydrocephalus, and delayed cerebral ischemia (DCI).

Epidemiology:

 
  • Age/ Gender: Most of the SAH occurs between age of 40-60, mean rupture age 50-55 and slightly more prevalent in females.
  • Risk Factors: Smoking and history of ruptured aneurysms increase SAH risk.

Etiology:

 
  • Aneurysmal SAH (aSAH):
    • Risk Factors: Hypertension, smoking, family history, alcohol use, sympathomimetic drugs, and estrogen deficiency.
    • Rupture Risk: (Option D)
      • Age >60
      • Posterior circulation aneurysms
      • Atherosclerosis
      • Aneurysm size
        • Aneurysms <10 mm: ~0.1% annual rupture risk.
        • Aneurysms ≥10 mm: 0.5–1% annual rupture risk.
        • Giant aneurysms (>2.5 cm): ~6% rupture risk in first year.
      • Family history
      • Previous SAH
      • ADPKD
  • Nonaneurysmal SAH (NASAH):
    • Perimesencephalic NASAH: Localized blood in perimesencephalic cisterns, normal angiography, benign course.
    • Occult Aneurysm: Small aneurysms missed on initial angiography, detectable on repeat imaging.
    • Vascular Malformations: Includes arteriovenous malformations (AVM) and dural arteriovenous fistulae. Treated with surgery or endovascular interventions.
    • Intracranial Arterial Dissection: Diagnosed by angiography, causes severe bleeding, treated with surgery or endovascular methods.
    • Other Causes: Cocaine abuse, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, cerebral venous thrombosis, sickle cell disorders, moyamoya disease, cerebral vasculitis, bleeding disorders.

Pathophysiology:

 
  • Hemodynamic Stress: Central to intracranial aneurysm formation, especially at arterial bifurcations.
  • Aneurysm Rupture: Causes neurological damage through compression of adjacent brain tissue and ischemia from reduced blood flow.
    • Mechanisms: Hemodynamic stress and inflammation (matrix metalloproteinase (MMP)-mediated degradation of extracellular matrix) weaken the arterial wall, promoting aneurysm formation and rupture.
    • Inflammatory Response: Macrophages and smooth muscle cells drive these degenerative processes.

questions.text: A 20 Y/O female presents to the clinic with a history of intermittent muscle weakness, which often follows periods of rest after exercise. She also reports occasional episodes of palpitations. On examination, she has mild facial dysmorphism, including a broad forehead, a small jaw, and low-set ears. Her pulse is irregular, and an ECG shows frequent premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) with occasional runs of bidirectional ventricular tachycardia. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the KCNJ2 gene. Which of the following best describes the underlying cause of this patient’s condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Sodium channelopathy affecting the cardiac conduction system

options.label: B
options.text: Potassium channelopathy affecting skeletal muscle and cardiac conduction

options.label: D
options.text: Abnormal chloride transport in skeletal and cardiac muscle

questions.correct_answer: B. Potassium channelopathy affecting skeletal muscle and cardiac conduction

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of generalized muscle weakness, particularly in his legs, after a day of strenuous exercise followed by a high-carbohydrate meal. He reports experiencing similar episodes of muscle weakness in the past, often triggered by exercise or large meals. His ECG shows U waves. What is the most appropriate first-line treatment for this patient’s acute presentation?

An 18-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe muscle weakness, primarily in his legs, which started a few hours after consuming a large, carbohydrate-heavy meal following exercise. He reports similar episodes in the past, often triggered by large meals or after rest following physical activity. His vital signs are stable, and he has no respiratory involvement. Blood work reveals a serum potassium level of 2.3 mEq/L. What is the most likely underlying mechanism for this patient's condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Sodium channel dysfunction causing an inability to generate action potentials

options.label: B
options.text: Potassium channel dysfunction leading to excessive potassium loss

options.label: C
options.text: Calcium or sodium channel mutations causing abnormal potassium influx into cells

options.label: D
options.text: Excessive release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction

questions.correct_answer: C. Calcium or sodium channel mutations causing abnormal potassium influx into cells

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of muscle stiffness, especially in his face and hands, following exposure to cold weather. He reports that his symptoms worsen with repeated movements and improve with rest. Upon examination, his muscles are stiff but not weak. His symptoms do not improve with warming .What is the most likely diagnosis?
